comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The saxophone looks a little unusual to me,  in an otherwise classical orchestra.  I presume that is the conductor centre front;  who is the lady on his right - a singer?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Maybe a singer, alright! She has sheet music rolled up, and she's the only one without an instrument...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: A wild guess for the location would be Waterford City hall or the Theater Royal. Unfortunately I'm a little too far away to pop in a take a look.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Its definitely not Waterford City Hall ( The Large Room) and is not the Theatre Royal. I believe that it may be St Catherine's Hall and Sunday School in Catherine Street Waterford, aka the Protestant hall. It has been altered since the photo, but will check out location in next few days. DG

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04/] That would have been my second wild guess.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] That'd be great, thanks for going to that trouble for us! And thank you [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] for those wild guesses.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Went to see St Catherine's Hall, which I am fairly certain is the site of the pic. It has been divided internally with the insertion of an extra floor and is now used as offices. There is some debate that original features were preserved behind protective stud partition walls.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Sorry for slow reply, Desmond! Have added the location on Catherine Street now.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 78516474@N00
comment._content: The pillar and clock look very similar to those in the council chamber of Cork City Hall, however that would have been impossible because the City Hall was burned in the "Burning of Cork" in December 1920 and the new one did not open until 1936.  I suppose they could have bought the clock and pillars from Waterford.
